   Assessment and Plan
   74F with newly diagnosed metastatic ovarian cancer on pressors and [**Hospital 1460**]
   transferred from west to [**Hospital Ward Name 1437**] ICU for ureteral stenting and
   possible palliative chemo.  Originally presented to ED [**2-22**] ARF and
   hyperkalemia now s/p ureteral stent and one day of chemotherapy.  PMH
   includes hypothyroidism and HLD.
   # Respiratory failure: Restrictive physiology given effusions, ascities
   and massive anasarca. Patient respiratory status slowly improving, now
   with lower PEEP and Plateau pressures. CXR looks much improved after
   draining both sides of chests, but now looks similar to yesterday. Lung
   parenchyma looks clear. Balance yesterday was positive since patient
   received fluid for increase CVP.
   -Decrease sedation
   -Monitor secretions
   -Wean from ventilatior to pressure support if possible
   -Clamp chest tube (right)
   -Start meropenem for ESBL enterobacter
   #) Hypotension
 Patient has been ruled out multiple times for
   myocardial ischemia and has an echocargriogram with good EF showing
   hyperdynamic heart. Patient with negative cultures and the only
   bacteria we have is ESBL enterobacter in sputum to explain sepsis. No
   signs of PE to explain obstructive physiology (or PTX, pericardial
   effusion). CVP increased to 14 with lower PEEP. Patient requiring less
   levophed than yesterday.
   -Try to wean down levophed
   -RBCs today
   - continue hydrocortisone IV 50mg q6h
   -Blood cultures
   -Start meropenem
   -Stop Zosyn
    # Renal failure: Initially ARF now patient on CVVH; adjusted yesterday
   by renal for metabolic acidosis and hypotension. Unclear etiology of
   hematuria/erythrocyturia.
   -monitor renal recs
   -monitor electrolytes closely
   -fluid restrict given fluid overload state
   -on levophed for hypotension
   -continue fluconazole for urine yeast infection
   # Malignancy- Patient with presumed metastatic ovarian cancer. 1 dose
   of chemo [**10-1**] day #1 with carboplatin 200 mg/m2 with BSA of 1.66.
   Tentative plan of second dose 21 days after the first if patient
   responds to first dose after several days. According to oncology,
   patients WBC may not drop for another 10-14days which will indicate
   whether first dose was adequate and/or if treatment is working. At this
   point there is no utility in following further cytology- thus far her
   pleural fluid was consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma, possibly
   primary ovarian ca. Onc attending has spoken to family at length and
   they are aware that this is not a curative intervention, rather it may
   help to get her home and prolong life for some number of months. On CT
   being done today will be able to evaluate if mass has changed in size
   since last imaging study earlier on admission.
   -f/u onc recommendations
   -F/u CT scan report
    # Anemia of chronic disease; renal failure and blood loss in urine.
   -continue folic acid IV
   -Transfuse 1 RBC today and follw HCT
    # Hypothyroidism
 Consulted endocrinology to help elucidate if
   hypothyroidism could be cause of persistent hypotension.
   - continue levothyroxine
   #. Hyperlipidemia - cont home statin dose
    # FEN
 TPN  f/u nutrition recs, CVVH, replete lytes PRN
    Dispo: ICU care, cont to address goals of care with family
    Glycemic Control:  sliding scale insulin

The patient is a 74-year-old female with newly diagnosed metastatic ovarian cancer. She was admitted to the ICU for ureteral stenting and possible palliative chemotherapy. She has a history of hypothyroidism and hyperlipidemia. The patient presented with acute renal failure (ARF) and hyperkalemia. She has been on pressors and has undergone ureteral stenting. Her respiratory status is slowly improving, with lower PEEP and plateau pressures. The CXR shows improvement after draining both sides of the chest, with clear lung parenchyma.

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's restrictive physiology is due to effusions, ascites, and massive anasarca. There is a need to monitor secretions, wean from ventilation to pressure support if possible, clamp chest tube (right), and start meropenem for ESBL enterobacter.

2. Hypotension: The patient has been ruled out for myocardial ischemia and has an echocardiogram with good EF showing hyperdynamic heart. She requires less levophed than yesterday. The plan is to try to wean down levophed, give RBCs today, continue hydrocortisone IV 50mg q6h, get blood cultures, start meropenem, and stop Zosyn.

   74F with newly diagnosed metastatic ovarian cancer on pressors and [**Hospital 1460**]
   transferred from west to [**Hospital Ward Name 1437**] ICU for ureteral stenting and
   possible palliative chemo.  Originally presented to ED [**2-22**] ARF and
   hyperkalemia now s/p ureteral stent and one day of chemotherapy.  PMH
   includes hypothyroidism and HLD.
   # Respiratory failure: Restrictive physiology due to effusions,
   ascities and anasarca, that have improved after parasentesis, pleural
   fluid drained with chest tube, as well as ascities drainage. Patient
   O2 requirements much more imprioved.
   -Decrease sedation
   -Monitor secretions
   -SBT on 5/0 today
   -Clamp chest tube (right)
   -Continue meropenem for ESBL enterobacter
   #) Hypotension
 Patient off pressors now, with borderline blood
   pressure. Now much more improved. Negative cultures so far and only
   culture data is from sputum growing ESBL enterobacter. No signs of PE
   explaining obstructive physiology.
   Monitor BP
   Check RBCs
   -F/u Blood cultures
   -Continue meropenem
   # Renal failure: Initially ARF now patient on CVVH; adjusted yesterday
   by renal for metabolic acidosis and hypotension. Unclear etiology of
   hematuria/erythrocyturia.
   -monitor renal recs
   -monitor electrolytes closely
   -fluid restrict given fluid overload state
   -on levophed for hypotension
   -continue fluconazole for urine yeast infection
   # Malignancy- Patient with presumed metastatic ovarian cancer. 1 dose
   of chemo [**10-1**] day #1 with carboplatin 200 mg/m2 with BSA of 1.66.
   Tentative plan of second dose 21 days after the first if patient
   responds to first dose after several days. According to oncology,
   patients WBC may not drop for another 10-14days which will indicate
   whether first dose was adequate and/or if treatment is working. At this
   point there is no utility in following further cytology- thus far her
   pleural fluid was consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma, possibly
   primary ovarian ca. Onc attending has spoken to family at length and
   they are aware that this is not a curative intervention, rather it may
   help to get her home and prolong life for some number of months. On CT
   being done today will be able to evaluate if mass has changed in size
   since last imaging study earlier on admission.
   -f/u onc recommendations
   -F/u CT scan report
    # Anemia of chronic disease; renal failure and blood loss in urine.
   -continue folic acid IV
    # Hypothyroidism
 Consulted endocrinology to help elucidate if
   hypothyroidism could be cause of persistent hypotension.
   - continue levothyroxine
   #. Hyperlipidemia - cont home statin dose
    # FEN
 TPN  f/u nutrition recs, CVVH, replete lytes PRN
    Dispo: ICU care, cont to address goals of care with family
    Glycemic Control:  sliding scale insulin

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 74-year-old female with newly diagnosed metastatic ovarian cancer who was admitted to the ICU for ureteral stenting and possible palliative chemotherapy. She presented initially with acute renal failure (ARF) and hyperkalemia, which improved after ureteral stent placement. The patient has a history of hypothyroidism and hyperlipidemia. She is currently on mechanical ventilation with pressure support, off pressors, and receiving chemotherapy. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's restrictive physiology due to effusions, ascites, and anasarca has improved after pleural fluid drainage with a chest tube and ascites drainage. However, she may still be at risk for respiratory failure due to her underlying conditions.
2. Hypotension: The patient was previously hypotensive but is now off pressors with borderline blood pressure. Monitoring her blood pressure and checking for any signs of infection or other causes of hypotension is essential.
3. Renal Failure: The patient initially presented with ARF, which has been managed with continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH). She also has anemia of chronic disease, renal failure, and blood loss in urine.
4. Malignancy: The patient has presumed metastatic ovarian cancer and received one dose of chemotherapy. Further doses will depend on her response and WBC count. Monitoring her oncology recommendations and CT scan report is important.
5. Hypothyroid

Based on the provided information, the patient is a 74-year-old female with metastatic malignancy and likely ovarian primary who has had an evolution of significant sepsis and respiratory failure. The patient is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation in the ICU.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:
- Temperature: 36.5 C (97.7 F) with a maximum recorded temperature of 35.9 C (96.6 F)
- Heart rate: 90 bpm with a range of 72-99 bpm
- Blood pressure: 116/65 mmHg with a range of 86/52-122/77 mmHg

The patient has multiple lines and tubes in place, including an arterial line, central venous catheter, dialysis catheter, and multi-lumen catheter. She is receiving multiple medications, including antibiotics (meropenem), vasopressors (norepinephrine), insulin, and hydrocortisone.

The patient's current medical complications include:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is being closely monitored, and efforts are being made to minimize sedation to allow for a trial of spontaneous breathing. The patient's readiness for extubation will depend on her ability to maintain adequate respiratory function without mechanical support.
2. Sepsis: The patient continues to show signs of sepsis despite receiving appropriate antibiotic therapy. Her Levophed requirements indicate ongoing hemodynamic instability, and she will require continued volume support and hemodynamic monitoring.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient is undergoing continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH) due to acute renal failure.
4. Malignant Neoplasm: The patient's underlying malignancy requires further discussion regarding chemotherapy treatment.

- ventilator-associated pneumonia (V

Summary:
Based on the provided information, the patient is a 74-year-old female with metastatic malignancy and likely ovarian primary who has had significant sepsis and respiratory failure. The patient's current condition includes:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory support has been transitioned to pressure support ventilation (PSV), and she is tolerating it well. The plan is to continue monitoring the respiratory system and minimize sedation to allow for a trial of spontaneous breathing. If the respiratory system is stable, a spontaneous breathing trial (SBT) may be performed. It is important to maintain adequate control of pleural fluid volumes to maintain the chance of extubation optimally.
2. Sepsis: The patient continues to require norepinephrine to maintain mean arterial pressure (MAP). Cultures have been negative, and meropenem will be continued. The patient's central venous pressure (CVP) is at 12, indicating fluid balance needs to be maintained.
3. Acute Renal Failure: Continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) has been initiated due to hemodynamic instability.
4. Malignant Neoplasm: Further chemotherapy will need to be considered in discussion with oncology. There is currently no evidence of nadir from chemotherapy.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): Due to the patient being on mechanical ventilation, there is a risk of developing VAP

   74F with newly diagnosed metastatic ovarian cancer on pressors and [**Hospital 1460**]
   transferred from west to [**Hospital Ward Name 1437**] ICU for ureteral stenting and
   possible palliative chemo.  Originally presented to ED [**2-22**] ARF and
   hyperkalemia now s/p ureteral stent and one day of chemotherapy.  PMH
   includes hypothyroidism and HLD.
    # Respiratory failure: Likely secondary initially to restrictive
   physiology due to effusions, ascities and anasarca, that have improved
   after parasentesis, pleural fluid drained with chest tube, as well as
   ascities drainage. Patient
s now s/p intubation with improved
   oxygenation.
   -Monitor secretions
   - chest tube (right) is not putting out much, left chest tube continues
   to put out large volumes of fluid
   - f/u with IR recs regarding plans for continued drainage
   -Continue meropenem for [**Month/Day (2) 1899**] enterobacter
   - nebs PRN
   #) Hypotension
 Patient off pressors now, with good blood pressures.
   Negative cultures so far and only culture data is from sputum growing
   [**Month/Day (2) 1899**] enterobacter and urine in the yeast. No signs of PE explaining
   obstructive physiology. Concern for aspiration pneumonia now has
   completed 7+ day course of vancomycin, switched to meropenem with new
   data for [**Last Name (LF) 1899**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] continue for now
   - Monitor BP
   - d/c fluconazole as has completed course for fungiuria
   - weaning stress dose steroids, now on day 2 of 25 IV q 6, would plan
   to keep for 4 days total before wean furthur
    # Renal failure: Initially ARF now patient on CVVH has been running
   even likely secondary to ATN, does not appear to be reversible..
   Unclear etiology of hematuria/erythrocyturia.
   -discussed with renal this AM plan to transition care to HD so that
   patient can leave ICU, as currently only thing keeping patient here is
   CVVH. As previously had hypotension in the setting of HD, and just came
   off of pressors yesterday, suspect that makes sense to wait to
   reinitiate HD.
   - plan for HD Monday 6 am then monitor BP and if stable would transfer
   to OMED for furthur care, cont CVVH until Monday
   -monitor electrolytes closely
   -fluid restrict given fluid overload state
    # Malignancy- Patient with presumed metastatic ovarian cancer. 1 dose
   of chemo [**10-1**] day #1 with carboplatin 200 mg/m2 with BSA of 1.66.
   Unclear when second dose would be. At this point there is no utility in
   following further cytology- thus far her pleural fluid was consistent
   with metastatic adenocarcinoma, possibly primary ovarian ca. Onc
   attending has spoken to family at length and they are aware that this
   is not a curative intervention, rather it may help to get her home and
   prolong life for some number of months.
   - plan for repeat CT chest [**10-15**]
   - appreciate onc meeting yesterday with family and primary care to
   emphasize that prognosis is grave and that do not suspect that
   repeating chemo will make a difference
   - family continues to hope that chemo is the answer
   - discussed with renal this morning, that if patient cannot be
   transitioned to HD effectively than would like to consider that
   continued CVVH may be medically futile
   - would consider ethics consult as family is somewhat unreceptive to
   primary team, and does not appear to understand long term prognosis of
   patient
   # Anemia of chronic disease; renal failure and blood loss in urine.
   -continue folic acid IV
    # Hypothyroidism
 Consulted endocrinology to help elucidate if
   hypothyroidism could be cause of persistent hypotension.
   - continue levothyroxine
    #. Hyperlipidemia - cont home statin dose
   # FEN
 TPN , CVVH, replete lytes PRN

   whether first dose was adequate and/or if treatment is working. At this
   point there is no utility in following further cytology- thus far her
   pleural fluid was consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma, possibly
   primary ovarian ca. Onc attending has spoken to family at length and
   they are aware that this is not a curative intervention, rather it may
   help to get her home and prolong life for some number of months. On CT
   being done today will be able to evaluate if mass has changed in size
   since last imaging study earlier on admission.

   of the study. 2. Left PICC tip is in the right ventricle. 3. Multiple
   areas of patchy opacity in the right upper and lower lobes as
   well as some new nodules, most likely infection or aspiration. Suggest
   close attention on follow-up.
   4. Left-sided pigtail catheter tip is in the peritoneal space;
   previously it appeared to be pleural.
   5. Right greater than left pleural effusion. 6. Multiple bulky
   mesenteric nodes in the abdomen which are not significantly changed

Summary:
The patient is a 74-year-old female with newly diagnosed metastatic ovarian cancer who is currently in the ICU. She was admitted for respiratory distress and intubated but has since been extubated. The patient's medical history includes hypothyroidism and hyperlipidemia. She presented with acute renal failure and hyperkalemia, for which she underwent ureteral stenting. The patient received one dose of chemotherapy and is expected to receive another dose in 21 days if she responds well to the first dose. Her current condition includes respiratory failure due to effusions, hypotension, renal failure, malignancy, anemia of chronic disease, and hypothyroidism.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient's restrictive physiology is caused by effusions, ascites, and anasarca. These conditions have improved after paracentesis, pleural fluid drainage with a chest tube, and ascites drainage. However, the patient still has ongoing fluid drainage from the left chest tube, which needs to be monitored and managed appropriately.

2. Hypotension: The patient was previously on pressors but is now off them. Her blood pressure is borderline. Negative cultures have been obtained so far, and there are no signs of pulmonary embolism explaining the obstructive physiology. Monitoring the patient's blood pressure and continuing meropenem for ESBL enterobacter are recommended.

   74F with newly diagnosed metastatic ovarian cancer on pressors and [**Hospital 1460**]
   transferred from west to [**Hospital Ward Name 1437**] ICU for ureteral stenting and
   possible palliative chemo.  Originally presented to ED [**2-22**] ARF and
   hyperkalemia now s/p ureteral stent and one day of chemotherapy.  PMH
   includes hypothyroidism and HLD.
    # Respiratory failure: Patient with baseline restrictive physiology
   due to effusions, ascities, anasarca, with resolving aspiration
   pneumonia s/p bilateral chest tube placement and successful extubation
   on [**10-10**] now reintubated secondary to hypercarbia, acidemia and
   respiratory distress. Most likely etiology is that patient has been
   tiring out since extubation. During rounds, nursing reported patient
   L chest tube was putting out 150-300cc/hr. There is still question if
   tube is in peritoneum
   -Suction and nebs prn
   - R chest tube with minimal output, could be d/c
   - f/u with IR recs regarding plans for continued drainage
   -Continue meropenem for ESBL enterobacter
   -At this point if patient fails extubation or is kept intubated for
   several days she may need a trach. This should be discussed with family
   at next meeting.
   #) Hypotension
 Patient is currently on pressors since intubation and
   attempted to be weaned off. Negative cultures so far and only culture
   data is from sputum growing ESBL enterobacter and urine in the yeast.
   Concern for aspiration pneumonia now has completed 7+ day course of
   vancomycin, switched to meropenem with new data for ESBL(day
   1=[**2138-10-9**]), will continue for now. It is likely her hypotension is
   secondary to malignancy and rapid fluid shifts out of the IV space.
   Other etiologies such as sepsis are also possible.
   - Monitor BP, fluid bolus if needed but w/caution given fluid overload
   -On CVVH, with attempt to keep even or slightly + for now.
   - stress dose steroids, now on day 3 of 25 IV q 6, one more day then
   titrate down
    # Renal failure: Initially ARF now patient on CVVH has been running
   even likely secondary to ATN, does not appear to be reversible. Given
   patient
s long-standing dependence on CVVH and HD, will need to assess
   what our end-point is. Given her reintubation today, will continue CVVH
   for now and touch base with renal to see if HD is still possible, which
   seems unlikely given hypotension/pressor dependence.
   -discussed with renal this AM plan to transition care to HD tomorrow
   however given re-intubation will need to reassess goals
   -monitor electrolytes closely
   -monitor fluids,
    # Malignancy- Patient with presumed metastatic ovarian cancer. 1 dose
   of chemo [**10-1**] day #1 with carboplatin 200 mg/m2 with BSA of 1.66.
   Unclear when second dose would be. At this point there is no utility in
   following further cytology- thus far her pleural fluid was consistent
   with metastatic adenocarcinoma, possibly primary ovarian ca. Onc
   attending has spoken to family at length and they are aware that this
   is not a curative intervention, rather it may help to get her home and
   prolong life for some number of months.
   - plan for repeat CT chest 9/24 per onc
   - family continues to hope that chemo is the answer
   - would consider ethics consult as family is somewhat unreceptive to
   primary team, and does not appear to understand long term prognosis of
   patient
   # Anemia of chronic disease; renal failure and blood loss in urine.
   -continue folic acid IV
    # Hypothyroidism
 Consulted endocrinology to help elucidate if
   hypothyroidism could be cause of persistent hypotension.
   - continue levothyroxine
   - recheck TFTs on [**10-13**] per endo recs
    #. Hyperlipidemia - cont home statin dose
   # FEN

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old female with a history of metastatic ovarian cancer. She has been admitted to the ICU for ureteral stenting and possible palliative chemotherapy.

The patient's current medical conditions include respiratory failure, hypotension, renal failure, anemia of chronic disease, hypothyroidism, hyperlipidemia, and febrile neutropenia.

The potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is reintubated due to hypercarbia, acidemia, and respiratory distress. There is a concern for aspiration pneumonia, and it is recommended to suction and nebulize the patient as needed. The possibility of a tracheostomy may be considered if the patient fails extubation or needs prolonged intubation.

2. Hypotension: The patient is on pressors since intubation and has negative cultures so far. She has completed a 7-day course of vancomycin for aspiration pneumonia and has switched to meropenem for ESBL enterobacter. The hypotension may be secondary to malignancy and rapid fluid shifts out of the IV space. Other etiologies such as sepsis are also possible. Close monitoring of blood pressure and cautious fluid administration are advised.

3. Renal failure: The patient initially presented with acute renal failure (ARF) and is currently on continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVH).

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 58-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with respiratory distress and subsequently intubated. The patient's condition has been stable, with a cardiac troponin level of 0.11 and a normal CK and CK-MB. The patient has been receiving multiple antibiotics and antiviral medication. Vital signs show a heart rate of 101 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 81-149 mmHg, respiratory rate of 34 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98%. The patient's weight has increased from 98.9 kg at admission to 107.3 kg currently. Fluid balance shows an intake of 8,502 mL and output of 9,066 mL, resulting in a negative balance of 564 mL. The patient is on respiratory support with an aerosol-cool oxygen delivery device and has an ABG showing pH 7.31, PaCO2 64 mmHg, and PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 190. Physical examination reveals bilateral rhonchi, tachypnea, bilateral edema, and no cyanosis. Laboratory results indicate elevated white blood cell count, low hemoglobin level, slightly elevated creatinine, and abnormal electrolyte levels. The patient is receiving total parenteral nutrition (TPN) and dialysis catheter placement.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is on mechanical ventilation

 Patient off pressors now, with good blood pressures.

   obstructive physiology. Concern for aspiration pneumonia now has
   completed 7+ day course of vancomycin, switched to meropenem with new
   data for [**Last Name (LF) 1899**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] continue for now
   - Monitor BP, fluid bolus if needed but w/caution given fluid overload

Summary:
Based on the provided information, the patient is a 74-year-old female with newly diagnosed metastatic ovarian cancer. She has been admitted to the ICU for ureteral stenting and possible palliative chemotherapy. The patient's medical history includes hypothyroidism and hyperlipidemia. 

The patient's current condition includes respiratory failure due to aspiration pneumonia, hypotension, renal failure requiring continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH), and anemia of chronic disease. The patient also has a history of hyperkalemia, but it seems to be under control.

The patient is currently on multiple medications including piperacillin/tazobactam, acyclovir, fluconazole, vancomycin, meropenem, morphine sulfate, pantoprazole, lorazepam, and folic acid.

The potential medical complications that can arise include worsening respiratory failure, further deterioration of renal function, and complications related to her malignancy. The patient's overall prognosis is grave, and there may be discussions regarding the futility of certain treatments and end-of-life care.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 74-year-old female with a history of metastatic ovarian cancer, hypothyroidism, and atherosclerotic heart disease. She was admitted to the ICU for ureteral stenting and received palliative chemotherapy. The patient presented to the emergency department on [**2-22**] with respiratory failure, hypotension, and renal failure. She was initially intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation.

The patient has been on pressors since intubation and attempted to be weaned off. Negative cultures have been obtained so far, with only one positive culture growing ESBL enterobacter from the sputum and yeast from the urine. The patient has completed a 7-day course of vancomycin and switched to meropenem due to new data indicating ESBL production. Hypotension is likely secondary to malignancy and rapid fluid shifts out of the IV space, but other etiologies such as sepsis are also possible.

The patient's renal function initially presented as acute renal failure (ARF) but has now progressed to chronic renal failure, with the patient being on continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVH) for the past three weeks. The renal team is planning to transition care to hemodialysis (HD) tomorrow, but this may be reassessed given the recent reintubation.

Summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old overweight/obese female who presented with increasing work of breathing, hypercarbic respiratory failure, and acidosis. She was initially intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation. A chest tube was inserted due to pleural effusion and continuous drainage of pleural fluid. The patient has a history of renal impairment and is currently on multiple medications including antibiotics for suspected sepsis. She is also receiving TPN (total parenteral nutrition) and has multiple IV lines in place.

The patient's vital signs show hypotension with a blood pressure of 78/42 mmHg, tachycardia with a heart rate of 89 bpm, and tachypnea with a respiratory rate of 27 breaths per minute. Oxygen saturation is 100% on supplemental oxygen. The patient's CVP (central venous pressure) is low at 3 mmHg, indicating poor cardiac function or volume depletion. Bladder pressure is elevated at 26 mmHg, suggesting increased intra-abdominal pressure possibly due to obesity or ascites. Fluid balance shows an intake of 8,769 mL and output of 4,211 mL, indicating ongoing fluid losses.

Respiratory support includes endotracheal intubation, mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 400 mL and respiratory rate set at 16 breaths per minute. PEEP (positive end-expiratory pressure) is set at 5 cmH2

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old female with a history of metastatic ovarian cancer, hypothyroidism, and hyperlipidemia. She was admitted to the ICU for ureteral stenting and palliative chemotherapy. The patient's current medical complications include respiratory failure, hypotension, renal failure, anemia of chronic disease, hypothyroidism, and hyperlipidemia.

The patient initially presented with increasing work of breathing, hypercarbia, and acidemia, leading to reintubation. She has been on invasive ventilation since October 12th. The patient has a history of restrictive physiology due to effusions, ascites, anasarca, and resolving aspiration pneumonia. She was successfully extubated on October 10th but became tired and required reintubation.

The patient's hypotension is likely secondary to malignancy and rapid fluid shifts. She has negative cultures so far, but there is concern for aspiration pneumonia. The patient has been on pressors since intubation and has completed a 7-day course of vancomycin. She has been switched to meropenem due to ESBL enterobacter.

The patient also has renal failure initially presenting as acute renal failure (ARF), now on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) for three weeks. It does not appear to be reversible. Given the patient's long-standing dependence on CVVH and hemodialysis

The patient's chief complaints are respiratory failure and acute renal failure. The patient was intubated due to worsening respiratory distress, tachypnea, and hypoxemia. The patient has a history of metastatic malignancy with an unknown primary but suspected ovarian cancer. The patient also has ongoing renal compromise.

The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 36.9Â°C (98.5Â°F) and 35.6Â°C (96.1Â°F) at different times, heart rate between 77-97 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 69-97 mmHg, respiratory rate between 19-32 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation at 100%. The patient's rhythm is sinus rhythm.

The patient's flow sheet data indicates that they have received a significant amount of fluids, with a total in of 8,769 mL and a total out of 4,211 mL over the past 24 hours. The patient's blood products show a total out of 4,558 mL and 727 mL. The patient's urine output is 377 mL and 180 mL over the respective time periods.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 12.3 K/uL, hemoglobin of 9.0 g/dL, potassium of 4.2 mEq/L, sodium of 139 mEq/L, chloride of 103 mEq/L, bicarbonate of 27.8 %, BUN of 52 mg/dL, creatinine of 0.7 mg/dL, glucose of 120 mg/dL, and platelet count of 52 K/uL.

The patient's imaging shows an endotracheal tube at the carina and bilateral CTs in place. The patient also has a SCL in place with a PICC line overlying.

The assessment and plan include acute renal failure, acute respiratory failure, pleural effusions, hypotension, and metastatic malignancy. The patient is currently on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) for renal failure and will continue with this treatment. The patient is also on mechanical ventilation (CMV) with plans to switch to pressure support ventilation (PSV) with a goal of providing complete support. The patient may require nocturnal bilevel positive airway pressure (BIPAP) support if extubation is achieved.

The patient has pleural effusions, with plans to consider drainage of the right effusion due to risk of infection. The patient's hypotension is multifactorial, and the plan is to wean hydrocortisone and add midodrine and florinef to facilitate wean.

The patient has metastatic malignancy with an unknown primary tumor, and further treatment will be discussed with the oncology team based on response.

In terms of ICU care, the patient is on nutrition via a nasogastric tube (NGT), with a goal of advancing

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 74-year-old female with metastatic ovarian cancer who has been admitted to the ICU. She is currently on CVVH (continuous veno-venous hemofiltration) and pressors for hypotension. The patient had an unsuccessful attempt at extubation due to hypercarbia and respiratory distress, leading to reintubation. She also has a history of hypothyroidism, anemia of chronic disease, renal failure, and blood loss in urine. The patient's chest tubes are producing minimal output, and there is no change in the chest x-ray. The family is considering a second opinion regarding the patient's cancer treatment. The oncology team has expressed that further chemotherapy may not be beneficial at this time. The patient is also growing yeast in the blood.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's reintubation indicates ongoing respiratory failure. Factors such as baseline restrictive physiology due to effusions, ascites, anasarca, and resolving aspiration pneumonia may contribute to her respiratory distress. Continuous monitoring and suctioning with nebulizers as needed should be implemented. The patient's low tidal volume and hypercarbia suggest the need for careful management of her ventilation settings.
2. Hypotension: The patient's persistent hypotension requires ongoing support with pressors. Negative cultures suggest that sepsis is less likely, but rapid fluid shifts due to malignancy could be a contributing factor. Monitoring

Summary:
The patient is a 74-year-old female with presumed metastatic ovarian cancer. She is currently in the ICU on CVVH (continuous veno-venous hemofiltration) and pressors, indicating severe renal failure and hypotension. She has been intubated twice and has not shown improvement clinically. The patient has a history of hypothyroidism and hypolipidemia. Her recent medical history includes aspiration pneumonia, for which she received bilateral chest tube placement and antibiotics.

The patient's current condition is as follows:
- Respiratory failure: She has a baseline restrictive physiology due to effusions, ascites, anasarca, and resolving aspiration pneumonia. She was successfully extubated on 10/10 but was reintubated due to hypercarbia, acidemia, and respiratory distress. It is likely that she is tiring out since extubation.
- Hypotension: She is on pressors since intubation and attempted to be weaned off. Negative cultures so far, but there is a concern for aspiration pneumonia. She has completed a 7+ day course of vancomycin and switched to meropenem for ESBL enterobacter, with new data indicating ESBL production (day 1=10/9). She also has yeast growing in the blood, and consideration should be given to restarting fluconazole. It is important to monitor her blood pressure and fluid balance closely.
- Renal failure: Initially acute renal

Summary:
The patient is a 74-year-old female with a history of widely metastatic malignancy and suspected ovarian carcinoma primary. She is currently in the ICU for persistent and significant respiratory failure, hypotension, renal failure, and oncology evaluation for possible response to chemotherapy. The patient's status remains one of continued full support and an absence of obvious change in response to chemotherapy based on initial CT scan.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure Acute: The patient has persistent and significant respiratory failure. The plan is to continue with pressure support ventilation (PSV) wean and move to respiratory system burden index (RSBI) today. Recurrent intubations may necessitate tracheostomy due to recurrent respiratory failure and risk of ongoing volume overload and hypercarbic respiratory failure. An alternative would be [Hospital1]-level mask ventilation support.
2. Pleural Effusions: The patient has malignant effusions with recurrent respiratory failure, which may contribute to the respiratory failure. It is planned to recheck the film following clamp of chest tubes x 24 hours.
3. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension appears to be a combination of limited effective circulating volume and decreased systemic vascular resistance (SVR), requiring the use of norepinephrine. There is a concern about yeast in the blood culture, and treatment for fungemia will be initiated.
4. Acute Renal Failure: The patient has continued oliguria but with some return of urine

    # Respiratory failure: Patient with baseline restrictive physiology
   due to effusions, ascities, anasarca, with resolving aspiration
   pneumonia s/p bilateral chest tube placement and successful extubation
   on [**10-10**] now reintubated secondary to hypercarbia, acidemia and
   respiratory distress. On PS 10/5 FIO2 40%, may be able to be
   successfully extubated however given multiple extubations may have to
   consider tracheostomy instead. This may or may not be consistent with
   goals of care discussed at yesterday
s meeting. IP consult noted chest
   tubes will have to be moved eventually but will hold off until second
   opinion by DF this week.
   -Suction and nebs prn
   - R and L chest tubes with some drainage, clamped with no change on
   xray
   -Continue meropenem for ESBL enterobacter (Day [**6-29**])
   -Continue caspofungin for yeast in blood, sputum and urine (Day [**5-23**]
   change when speciated)
   # Hypotension
 Patient off pressors as of 6am today. Has been on/off
   since admission for hypotension of unclear etiology. As far as
   infectious etiologies-  enterobacter in sputum and yeast in urine,
   sputum and blood; also witnessed aspiration at beginning of admission,
   for which she completed 7+ day course of vancomycin, switched to
   meropenem for ESBL(day 1=[**2138-10-9**]). She has also been on steroids
   (stress dose) for concern of adrenal insufficiency and has been quite
   responsive. However, most likely etiology is underlying malignancy and
   rapid fluid shifts.
   - convering infections with meropenem and caspofungin (given failure on
   fluconazole)
   - off pressors, will continue monitoring BP and CVP
   - continue PO prednisone taper
   - fluid bolus prn for hypotension
    # Renal failure: Initially ARF now patient on CVVH for prolonged
   course, and renal insult appears unlikely to resolve at this point.
   Given her hypotension we are unable to switch to HD. Will continue CVVH
   for now.

   ovarian cancer. Per family meeting yesterday will get second opinion

   malignancy.
   - awaiting [**Hospital3 1956**] evaluation
   - f/u any oncology recommendations
   - appreciate social work input and involvement
   # Anemia of chronic disease; renal failure and blood loss in urine.
   -continue folic acid in TPN

   - continue levothyroxine

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old female with a history of metastatic ovarian cancer, hypothyroidism, and hyperlipidemia. She was admitted to the ICU for ureteral stenting and has been experiencing multiple medical complications.

The patient's current condition includes:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient initially had resolving aspiration pneumonia but has now developed respiratory distress due to hypercarbia and acidemia. She is on mechanical ventilation with PSV mode, FiO2 of 40%, and PEEP of 5 cmH2O. There is a discussion about the possibility of tracheostomy if extubation fails again.
2. Hypotension: The patient has been experiencing hypotension of unclear etiology. She has been on and off pressors since admission. Possible causes include underlying malignancy, rapid fluid shifts, and infections (enterobacter in sputum and yeast in blood, sputum, and urine).
3. Renal failure: Initially acute renal failure (ARF), the patient is now on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) due to a prolonged course of renal insult. Switching to hemodialysis (HD) is not possible due to hypotension.
4. Malignancy: The patient has presumed metastatic ovarian cancer. She received one dose of chemotherapy with carboplatin but requires further evaluation and treatment by an oncology consultant.

The patient is a 58-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of persistent hypotension. The patient has a history of allergies to oxycodone and nausea/vomiting. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 35.9Â°C (96.6Â°F), heart rate of 93 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 114/65 to 85 mmHg, respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The patient is intubated and sedated, but appears comfortable. Physical examination findings include decreased breath sounds at bases, expiratory wheeze, and no new skin lesions. Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, slightly low hemoglobin and platelet levels, and normal glucose levels. The patient is receiving total parenteral nutrition and has multiple lines in place for various procedures.

Potential Medical Complications:
Based on the information provided, potential medical complications that can arise include ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcers, and catheter-related bloodstream infections. The patient's prolonged intubation increases the risk of VAP, while the presence of central venous catheters raises the risk of DVT and catheter-related bloodstream infections. Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old female with metastatic adenocarcinoma of likely ovarian origin. She has been experiencing prolonged ventilatory failure and sepsis. The patient's current condition includes respiratory failure, acute renal failure, sepsis, and metastatic malignancy.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient still requires positive airway pressure support (PSV) with a set tidal volume (Vt) of 280-330 mL and respiratory rate (RR) of 35-40 breaths per minute. This suggests an inability to provide safe extubation. The goal is to maintain effective ventilation and achieve a negative fluid balance to potentially trial extubation in the next day. If extubation is not successful, re-intubation may be considered.
2. Acute Renal Failure: Continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) is ongoing to manage the acute renal failure. The main goal is to achieve a negative fluid balance today.
3. Sepsis: The patient has fungemia being treated with caspofungin, and other cultures are negative at this time. Midodrine is in place to support blood pressure, and the central venous line (CVL) may need to be discontinued due to the presence of fungemia. Steroids are being weaned off, and the focus remains on stabilizing blood pressure.

   Assessment and Plan
   74F with thought metastatic ovarian cancer s/p one cycle of palliative
   chemotherapy, on pressors and [**Hospital 1460**] transferred from west to [**Hospital Ward Name 1437**]
   ICU for ureteral stenting. PMH includes hypothyroidism and HLD.
    # Respiratory failure: Patient with restrictive pneumopathy due to
   anasarca of the chest wall, tumor burden in the abdomen, ascities. Her
   baseline Vt are ~300 and most of it goes into death space. Has required
   re-intubation multiple times for getting tired and CO2 slowly rises.
   Patient unable to blow high amount of CO2 due to low tidal volumes.
   Patient on AC overnight and switched back to PS during the day. Left
   chest tube with ~700 cc/hr yesterday at some point, so it was clamped.
   Right one with ~2L /24 hrs.
   -          Continue PS for now
   -          Maintain even balance
   -          Re-start CVVH tomorrow when line placed and try to remove
   fluid and improve chest compliance
   -          F/u IP recs for chest tubes; will keep them in to improve
   respiratory failure
   -          Minimize fluids through IVs
   -          Continue meropenem (Day [**7-29**]) and caspofungin (Day 3)
   -          F/u cultures
   # Hypotension
 Patient back on pressors. Behaving as septic
   physiology, but etiology unclear. The only source of bacteria is sputum
   ESBL enterobacter in the setting of witnessed aspiration. Patient
   tomorrow finished the course of meropenem. Patient growing fungi in
   blood and urine, now on casponfungin after failing fluconazole. Also,
   adrenal insufficiency may be contributing to the hypotension. Patient
   on steroid replacement therapy.
   -Continue meropenen ([**7-29**])
   -Continue caspogungin (Day 3)
   -Taper prednisone (10mg/day today)
   -Wean Levophed slowly
   -Maintain negative balance: goal 500cc
   -CVP goal 8mm H2O
   -Continue midodrine at 5mg [**Hospital1 7**]
   # Renal failure: Patient on renal failure; acute setting requiring HD
   and now prolonged course of CVVH (3 weeks). Post renal component s/p
   stent placed, pre-renal component with hypotension and persistent
   pressor support and there may be a renal component as well. Patient now
   with increasing urine output (Slowly). If it picks up, may be of good
   prognosis.
   -CVVH tomorrow
   -f/u renal recs
   -f/u PM lytes (potassium)
   -monitor electrolytes, fluid closely
    # Malignancy- Patient with presumed metastatic ovarian cancer. 1 dose
   of chemo [**10-1**] day #1 with carboplatin 200 mg/m2 with BSA of 1.66.
   Cytology consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma, possibly primary
   ovarian cancer. Per family meeting yesterday will get second opinion
   from [**Hospital3 1956**] and plan accordingly at that point. A repeat CT showed
   no change in abdominopelvic lymphadenopathy consistant with her
   malignancy.
   - awaiting [**Hospital3 1956**] evaluation
   - f/u any oncology recommendations
   - appreciate social work input and involvement
   # Anemia of chronic disease; renal failure and blood loss in urine.
   -continue folic acid
   # Hypothyroidism
 Consulted endocrinology to help elucidate if
   hypothyroidism could be cause of persistent hypotension.
   - continue levothyroxine
   - f/u endocrine recs
   #. Hyperlipidemia
 Not on statin, since patient not getting anything
   NPO. Not likely to absorb due to bowel edema.
   # FEN
 TF started yesterday, may need to switch to TPN when extubated.
   replete lytes PRN
   #Glycemic Control:  sliding scale insulin
   # Lines:
   Left IJ
   # Prophylaxis: heparin sq, PPI IV
   # Code status: Full code, reconfirmed goals of care on [**10-5**] with family
 want intubation and full resuscitation
   # Dispo: ICU care for now, until extubated.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Nutren 2.0 (Full) - [**2138-10-15**] 06:16 PM 30 mL/hour

   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:

Summary:
The patient is a 74-year-old female with a history of metastatic ovarian cancer, hypothyroidism, and hyperlipidemia. She is currently admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure, hypotension, renal failure, and anemia of chronic disease. The patient has been receiving palliative chemotherapy and is on pressors for hypotension. She also has anasarca, ascites, and chest wall restriction due to her malignancy. The patient's vital signs show a heart rate of 92 bpm, blood pressure of 78/68 mmHg, respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100% on endotracheal tube with CPAP. Her temperature is slightly elevated at 36.6 degrees Celsius.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's restrictive pneumopathy due to anasarca and tumor burden in the abdomen, along with ascites, increases her risk of respiratory failure. She has required reintubation multiple times and is on positive pressure ventilation support.

2. Hypotension: The patient is experiencing persistent hypotension despite pressor support. The etiology is unclear, but it may be due to septic physiology, adrenal insufficiency, or other factors. The patient has been on multiple antibiotics and antifungal medications.

3. Renal Failure: The patient has acute renal failure requiring dialysis and has been on a prolonged course of continuous veno-

Summary:
Based on the information provided in the progress note, the patient's chief complaint is ARF (acute renal failure), SOB (shortness of breath), anasarca (generalized edema), and oliguria (decreased urine output). 

The patient has a history of metastatic ovarian cancer and has undergone one cycle of palliative chemotherapy. They also have hypothyroidism and HLD (history of heart disease).

The patient's current medical condition includes respiratory failure due to restrictive pneumopathy caused by anasarca of the chest wall, tumor burden in the abdomen, and ascites. They have required reintubation multiple times for fatigue and CO2 slowly rises. The patient is unable to blow off high amounts of CO2 due to low tidal volumes. They are on AC (assisted control) overnight and switched back to PS (pressure support) during the day. 

The patient's hypotension is behaving like septic physiology, but the etiology is unclear. The only source of bacteria is sputum ESBL enterobacter in the setting of witnessed aspiration. The patient has finished the course of meropenem and is growing fungi in blood and urine, now on caspofungin after failing fluconazole. Adrenal insufficiency may also be contributing to the hypotension, and the patient is on steroid replacement therapy.

The patient has renal failure, requiring HD (hemodialysis) and CVVH (continuous veno-venous

   74 yo female with metastatic adenocarcinoma now with persistent
   ventilatory failure, renal failure and sepsis with most recent pathogen

   -Based upon patient wishes will have to decide on course of extubation

   -Currently not expected to be able to tolerate extubation given current

Summary:
The patient is a 74-year-old female with metastatic adenocarcinoma, now experiencing persistent ventilatory failure, renal failure, and sepsis. The patient's current condition includes:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has high output from chest tubes due to malignant effusions, resulting in persistent ventilatory failure. Despite drainage of fluids, there has been minimal improvement, suggesting that the abdominal malignancy process is the primary driver of the persistent ventilatory failure. The patient's chest wall mechanics are restricted, making extubation not currently expected to be tolerated.

2. Sepsis: The possible fungal source of infection is being treated with caspofungin for initial treatment of fungal cultures. Additionally, meropenem is being administered for enterobacter treatment. Pressors are being used to maintain blood pressure, and efforts are being made to wean them off over time.

3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient has evidence of persistent limited urine flow but currently shows no indication for return to dialysis. Renal function will be re-evaluated daily for any signs of improvement.

4. Metastatic Malignancy: Due to the patient's condition, further chemotherapy is not recommended. It is suggested to clamp the chest tube with intermittent drainage. No other interventions based on the oncology team's evaluation are planned. The patient's goals for care will need to be evaluated in the absence of reversible progression of malignancy.

In terms of ICU care,

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 74-year-old female with newly diagnosed metastatic ovarian cancer. She is currently on pressors and previously on CVVH, transferred from west to east ICU for ureteral stenting. The patient has not responded to chemotherapy and is now experiencing persistent ventilatory failure, renal failure, and sepsis caused by a fungal infection. The patient's family has not been able to obtain a second opinion yet.

24-Hour Events:
- Dr. [Last Name (STitle)] spoke with the patient's family and explained the patient's condition, including that she is dying.
- The patient's son has not found an oncologist willing to come and see the patient.
- An ophthalmology consultation was performed, indicating no signs of [Female First Name] in the eye.
- Foley catheter was discontinued, with minimal urine output since then.
- Nursing is unable to scan the bladder due to large volume edema.
- The patient has significant body swelling (anasarca).
- Allergies include oxycodone, nausea/vomiting, and antibiotics.
- Infusions include midazolam, norepinephrine, and pantoprazole.
- Other ICU medications are morphine sulfate and caspofungin.

   Assessment and Plan
   74 yo female with metastatic adenocarcinoma now with persistent
   ventilatory failure, renal failure and sepsis with most recent pathogen
   identified as fungus present within blood, urine and sputum cultures.
   Her sepsis did appear to transiently improve with antibacterial therapy
   and we were able to D/C IV pressors, however, we now have had recurrent
   decline in the setting of positive fungal cultures.
    1)Respiratory Failure-Continued high output from chest tubes due to
   malignant effusions.  Have no capacity to maintain favorable
   ventilatory mechanics despite drainage of fluids which would suggest
   that abdominal malignancy process is primary driver of persistent
   ventilatory failure.  Patient is currently requiring increased
   ventilatory support.
   - leave chest tube clamped for today with plan for intermittient
   drainage as needed for pulmonary support
   -Patient with likely persistent restriction of chest wall mechanics
   with abdominal malignancy and has been minimally improved with chest
   tube drainage.
   -Alb/Atrovent nebs PRN
   -Currently not expected to be able to tolerate extubation given current
   ventilatory mechanics, expect that might initially be successful for a
   day or so as before
   2)Sepsis-Possible fungal source of infection
   -Meropenem-for enterobacter treatment
   -Caspofungin-for initial treatment of fungal cultures
   - seen by opthalmology who did not see any evidence of fungus in the
   retina
   -Levophed, will continue to try to wean as tolerated
   -Pred 20mg/d
   -IVF bolus as needed to look to wean pressors (yesterday recieved 500
   cc bolus, 250 cc bolus) however suspect that all of this fluid in
   extravascular space, will again give 500 cc NS this morning for low CVP
   and continue to bolus PRN
   - keep brachial a-line for now, if fails to improve clinically consider
   switching out the lines
   - repeat blood cultures
   3)Acute Renal Failure--Had evidence of persistent limited urine flow
   but right now no evidence of need for return to dialysis
   - d/c foley yesterday with only 100 cc of urine produced. bladder scan
   showed no fluid in the bladder however this is obviously limited by
   diffuse whole body anasarca, nursing unable yet to replace foley
   catheter due to whole body swelling
   - this AM with large volume of incontinent urine
   - currently electrolytes are OK, although K 5.0
   - do not think that patient should be offerred furthur CVVH or HD at
   this time given clinical scenario
   - check PM lytes
   - monitor UOP
   4)Metastatic Malignancy-
   -No further chemotherapy recommended per oncology here
   -Favor clamp of chest tube with intermittent drainage
   -No other role for intervention based upon oncology team here.
   -Will need to evalaute patient's goals for care in the setting of
   absence of reversible progression of malignancy

   PPx- penumoboots, heparin subQ

Summary:
The patient is a 74-year-old female with newly diagnosed metastatic ovarian cancer. She is currently on pressors and previously underwent CVVH. She was transferred from the west ICU to the east ICU for ureteral stenting. The patient has not responded to one round of chemotherapy, and her family has not been able to obtain a second opinion. The patient's condition is deteriorating, with persistent ventilatory failure, renal failure, and sepsis caused by a fungal infection. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient requires increased ventilatory support due to malignant effusions and restriction of chest wall mechanics caused by abdominal malignancy.
2. Sepsis: The patient has a fungal infection, which is a possible source of infection. She has already received treatment with meropenem and caspofungin. Continuous monitoring and appropriate management of the infection are crucial.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's urine output is limited, and there is a concern about the need for dialysis. The presence of anasarca makes it difficult to replace the foley catheter. Regular monitoring of urine output and electrolytes is essential.
4. Metastatic Malignancy: The patient's metastatic malignancy is progressing, and further chemotherapy is not recommended. Evaluating the patient's goals for care in the setting of irreversible progression of malignancy is important.

Overall, the patient's condition is critical, and close monitoring and

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old female with metastatic adenocarcinoma. The patient has persistent hypotension and worsening respiratory failure, requiring CMV support for ventilation and oxygenation. The patient also has acute renal failure, sepsis, and malignancy.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is acute and chronic in nature. There is a decline in oxygenation and ventilation compared to the previous day. The patient requires full support from CMV, and chest tubes with large volume drainage may need to be clamped and drained intermittently.

2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient shows minimal evidence of return of renal function. There are no indications for dialysis at the moment, but it may need to be reconsidered in the setting of progressive clinical decline and no expectation for recovery.

3. Sepsis: The patient has sepsis, which is being treated with Levophed (norepinephrine), caspofungin, and meropenem. Prednisone is also being given at a dose of 10mg qd and will be tapered off. The goal CVP is maintained between 8-10, and bolus administration is done as necessary. All venous lines and Foley catheter have been changed due to candidemia.

4. Malignancy: The patient has metastatic adenocarcinoma, and no further treatment

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 74-year-old female with metastatic adenocarcinoma. She is currently in the ICU with persistent ventilatory failure, renal failure, and sepsis. The recent pathogen identified is a fungus present in blood, urine, and sputum cultures. The patient's sepsis initially improved with antibacterial therapy, but there has been a recurrent decline with positive fungal cultures. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient requires increased ventilatory support due to persistent high output from chest tubes caused by malignant effusions. The abdominal malignancy process is likely the primary driver of the ventilatory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient has a possible fungal source of infection. She was treated with meropenem, which has been discontinued, and caspofungin for the initial treatment of fungal cultures.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient had evidence of limited urine flow, but currently, there is no need for dialysis. However, she is incontinent of urine and continues to be monitored closely for potassium levels.
4. Metastatic Malignancy: The patient's metastatic malignancy is not reversible, and the family is working on obtaining a second opinion from an outside oncologist.

The patient is a 58-year-old male admitted to the ICU with an unknown primary diagnosis. The patient's vital signs are currently stable, but there have been fluctuations in blood pressure. The patient is receiving multiple medications, including antibiotics, sedatives, and vasopressors. Fluid balance and respiratory support are being closely monitored. The patient's laboratory values show some abnormalities, including elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, and elevated creatinine levels. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure has been fluctuating, indicating potential hypotension. This may require adjustment of vasopressor infusion rates or other interventions to maintain adequate blood pressure.
2. Infection: The patient is receiving antibiotics, suggesting a possible infection. It is important to monitor the patient's response to antibiotics and consider further diagnostic tests if necessary.
3. Fluid overload: The patient's fluid balance shows an intake of 3,481 mL and output of 3,100 mL, indicating a positive fluid balance. This could lead to fluid overload, which can have adverse effects on cardiac function and pulmonary status.
4. Kidney dysfunction: The elevated creatinine level suggests possible kidney dysfunction. Close monitoring of renal function and adjustment of medications accordingly is necessary.
5. Respiratory issues: The patient is receiving respiratory support, and his ABG results show some abnormalities. Continuous monitoring of oxygenation and ventilation parameters is essential to ensure adequate respiratory function.
6. Sedation and delirium: The patient is sedated with midazolam (versed), which can cause sedation and potentially delirium. Regular assessments of the patient's mental status and appropriate weaning of sedation should be considered.

   74 yo female with metastatic adenocarcinoma now with persistent
   ventilatory failure, renal failure and sepsis with most recent pathogen
   identified as fungus present within blood, urine and sputum cultures.
   Her sepsis did appear to transiently improve with antibacterial therapy
   and we were able to D/C IV pressors, however, we now have had recurrent
   decline in the setting of positive fungal cultures.
    1)Respiratory Failure-Continued high output from chest tubes due to
   malignant effusions.  Have no capacity to maintain favorable
   ventilatory mechanics despite drainage of fluids which would suggest
   that abdominal malignancy process is primary driver of persistent
   ventilatory failure.  Patient is currently requiring increased
   ventilatory support.
   - leave chest tube clamped for today with plan for intermittient
   drainage as needed for pulmonary support
   -Patient with likely persistent restriction of chest wall mechanics
   with abdominal malignancy and has been minimally improved with chest
   tube drainage.
   -Alb/Atrovent nebs PRN
   -Currently not expected to be able to tolerate extubation given current
   ventilatory mechanics, expect that might initially be successful for a
   day or so as before

   -Meropenem-for enterobacter treatment
   -Caspofungin-for initial treatment of fungal cultures
   - seen by opthalmology who did not see any evidence of fungus in the
   retina
   -Levophed, will continue to try to wean as tolerated
   -Pred 20mg/d
   -IVF bolus as needed to look to wean pressors (yesterday recieved 500
   cc bolus, 250 cc bolus) however suspect that all of this fluid in
   extravascular space, will again give 500 cc NS this morning for low CVP
   and continue to bolus PRN
   - keep brachial a-line for now, if fails to improve clinically consider
   switching out the lines
   - repeat blood cultures
   3)Acute Renal Failure--Had evidence of persistent limited urine flow
   but right now no evidence of need for return to dialysis
   - d/c foley yesterday with only 100 cc of urine produced. bladder scan
   showed no fluid in the bladder however this is obviously limited by
   diffuse whole body anasarca, nursing unable yet to replace foley
   catheter due to whole body swelling
   - this AM with large volume of incontinent urine
   - currently electrolytes are OK, although K 5.0
   - do not think that patient should be offerred furthur CVVH or HD at
   this time given clinical scenario
   - check PM lytes
   - monitor UOP
   4)Metastatic Malignancy-
   -No further chemotherapy recommended per oncology here
   -Favor clamp of chest tube with intermittent drainage
   -No other role for intervention based upon oncology team here.
   -Will need to evalaute patient's goals for care in the setting of
   absence of reversible progression of malignancy
   FEN: tube feeds, IVF bolus PRN
   PPx- penumoboots, heparin subQ

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 74-year-old female with metastatic adenocarcinoma. She has persistent ventilatory failure, renal failure, and sepsis, with the most recent pathogen identified as a fungus present in blood, urine, and sputum cultures. The patient's sepsis appeared to transiently improve with antibacterial therapy, but there has been a recurrent decline with positive fungal cultures.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient requires increased ventilatory support due to high output from chest tubes caused by malignant effusions. There is a restriction of chest wall mechanics due to abdominal malignancy, which has not been significantly improved with chest tube drainage. It is unlikely that the patient will be able to tolerate extubation given the current ventilatory mechanics.

2. Sepsis: The possible fungal source of infection needs to be addressed. The patient is currently receiving meropenem for enterobacter treatment and caspofungin for initial treatment of fungal cultures. Levophed will continue to be used as tolerated, and efforts will be made to wean the patient off pressors. Prednisone (Pred 20mg/d) has been prescribed. Blood cultures have been repeated.

   Assessment and Plan
   74 yo female with metastatic adenocarcinoma now with persistent
   ventilatory failure, renal failure and sepsis with most recent pathogen
   identified as fungus present within blood, urine and sputum cultures.
   Her sepsis did appear to transiently improve with antibacterial therapy
   and we were able to D/C IV pressors, however, we now have had recurrent
   decline in the setting of positive fungal cultures.
    1)Respiratory Failure-Continued high output from chest tubes due to
   malignant effusions.  Have no capacity to maintain favorable
   ventilatory mechanics despite drainage of fluids which would suggest
   that abdominal malignancy process is primary driver of persistent
   ventilatory failure.  Patient is currently requiring increased
   ventilatory support.
   - currently not on sedation
   -contact IP about chest tubes (will likely stay in and stay clamped for
   now)
   -Alb/Atrovent nebs PRN
   -continue to assess for extubation however unlikely today as pt still
   on AC
   2)Sepsis-Possible fungal source of infection
   -Meropenem-d/c today
   -Caspofungin-for initial treatment of fungal cultures
   -Levophed, will continue to try to wean as tolerated
   -Prednisone 10mg qd
   -f/u cultures
   3)Acute Renal Failure--Had evidence of persistent limited urine flow
   but right now no evidence of need for return to dialysis
   - d/c foley yesterday with only 100 cc of urine produced. bladder scan
   showed no fluid in the bladder however this is obviously limited by
   diffuse whole body anasarca, nursing unable yet to replace foley
   catheter due to whole body swelling
   - continues to be incontinent of urine
   - closely monitor K
   - if hyperkalemic- EKG, kayexelate, lasix if necessary
   -renally dose medications
   -attempt to keep I/O even
   4)Metastatic Malignancy-
   -Family is working on 2^nd opinion from outside oncologist
   -Favor clamp of chest tube with intermittent drainage
   -No other role for intervention based upon oncology team here.
   -Will need to evalaute patient's goals for care in the setting of
   absence of reversible progression of malignancy
   FEN: tube feeds, IVF bolus PRN
   PPx- penumoboots, heparin subQ

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 74-year-old female with metastatic adenocarcinoma who is experiencing persistent ventilatory failure, renal failure, and sepsis. The patient's respiratory failure is likely driven by the abdominal malignancy process. She is currently on increased ventilatory support and is not ready for extubation. Sepsis is suspected to be caused by a fungal infection, for which treatment with caspofungin has been initiated. The patient also has acute renal failure, and efforts are being made to manage her kidney function by monitoring potassium levels and administering medications accordingly. The patient's metastatic malignancy requires further evaluation and management, including obtaining a second opinion from an outside oncologist. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's persistent ventilatory failure may lead to further deterioration in lung function and difficulty weaning off the ventilator.
2. Sepsis: The ongoing infection, potentially of fungal origin, can progress and cause systemic inflammation, organ dysfunction, and potentially death if not effectively managed.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's renal function may continue to deteriorate, leading to electrolyte imbalances, fluid overload, and the need for dialysis.
4. Metastatic Malignancy: The progression of the underlying malignancy may lead to further complications and limitations in treatment options.

Please note that this summary and potential complications are based solely on the provided progress note.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 74-year-old female with metastatic ovarian cancer, pleural and pericardial effusions, and ascites. She has had a complicated course including acute respiratory failure, restrictive physiology due to malignant pleural effusions/ascites, hypotension requiring ongoing pressors, and acute renal failure on intermittent continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH). The patient also had fungemia caused by Candida albicans and has been pressor-dependent for over a month. She is currently on mechanical ventilation (ACV) with the CT (cannula/tracheostomy) remaining clamped. The patient's digit necrosis is new and may not be reversible given her prolonged pressor dependence. There are plans to switch to dopamine to maintain mean arterial pressure (MAP) without the same effect as levophed. Further tapering of prednisone is also planned. The patient's family is continuing to search for a second opinion regarding her metastatic ovarian cancer. In the ICU, the patient is receiving nutrition via Nutren Renal at 30 mL/hour, and her glycemic control is being monitored. She has multiple lines in place, including an arterial line and a multi-lumen line. Prophylaxis measures include DVT prevention with boots, stress ulcer prophylaxis with a proton pump inhibitor (PPI), and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) prevention with mouth care and head-of-bed

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 74-year-old female with metastatic adenocarcinoma presenting with persistent ventilatory failure, renal failure, and sepsis. She has positive fungal cultures in her blood, urine, and sputum. The patient has been intubated for more than three weeks and requires a tracheostomy. She has high output chest tubes, indicating ongoing pleural effusions. Her respiratory mechanics show low tidal volume, low respiratory system compliance, and high plateau pressures, suggesting a restrictive component possibly due to chest wall edema. The patient is aware and off sedation, with low secretions. 

The patient's sepsis is being treated with caspofungin, and she is still on levophed as pressors. Prednisone is being tapered down from 10mg to 5mg per day. Cultures will be followed up. 

The patient has acute renal failure with persistent oliguria and an increasing creatinine level. Hemodialysis or continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVH) may be needed soon, but no indication has been provided yet. 

Regarding the metastatic malignancy, the family is working on a second opinion from an outside oncologist. The oncology team here does not have any further intervention to offer. The patient's goals for care should be evaluated in the absence of reversible progression of malignancy. 

ICU care includes nutrition support through tube feeds,

   74 yo female with metastatic adenocarcinoma now with persistent
   ventilatory failure, renal failure and sepsis with most recent pathogen
   identified as fungus present within blood, urine and sputum cultures.
   Her sepsis did appear to transiently improve with antibacterial therapy

   # Respiratory Failure- Patient with aspiration PNA s/p treatment,
   bilateral pleural effusions that have been stable, ascities that
   slightly improved. Now with bilateral chest tubes, which have very high

   risbi, but gets tired easily after being extubated. She has
   continuously high peak pressures with high plateaus suggesting some
   restrictive component, which may be due to chest wall edema, since

   -Prednisone 10mg qd decreased to 5mg yesterday

   # Acute Renal Failure- Has persisten UOP, but it is not being
   quantified due to technical difficulties with her body habitus,
   anasarca and weeping skin. Creatinine slowly creeping up. [**Month (only) 51**] need

Summary:
Based on the provided information, the patient is a 74-year-old female with metastatic adenocarcinoma. She has persistent ventilatory failure, renal failure, and sepsis caused by a fungal infection, as indicated by positive fungal cultures in her blood, urine, and sputum. The patient's respiratory failure is due to aspiration pneumonia, bilateral pleural effusions, and ascites. She has been intubated for over three weeks and requires a tracheostomy. 

The patient is currently receiving norepinephrine (Levophed) to support her blood pressure, midazolam (Versed) for sedation, and various antibiotics for the fungal infection. She is also on caspofungin for initial treatment of the fungal infection. The patient's renal function is deteriorating, and she may soon require dialysis. 

In terms of potential medical complications, the patient is at risk for worsening respiratory failure, further deterioration of renal function leading to acute renal failure, and complications related to her metastatic malignancy. The patient's nutritional status is also a concern due to her inability to eat by mouth and the need for tube feeds. 

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management of multiple organ systems.

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has been intubated for over three weeks and requires a tracheostomy. She has low tidal volume, low respiratory system compliance, high peak pressures, and high plateaus suggesting restrictive lung disease, which may be due to chest wall edema.
2. Sepsis: The patient is suspected to have a fungal source of infection. She is receiving caspofungin for initial treatment of fungal cultures and will continue to be monitored with follow-up cultures.

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 74-year-old female with metastatic ovarian adenocarcinoma admitted to the ICU for persistent respiratory failure, hypotension requiring prolonged pressor support, acute renal failure requiring continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH), and candidemia.

The patient has completed antimicrobial therapy for aspiration pneumonia and has bilateral chest tubes in place, currently clamped off. A chest X-ray this morning suggests improved pleural effusion on the right and unchanged on the left. The patient has been intubated for a significant period of time and is likely to be difficult to extubate successfully in the short-term.

The patient has candidemia treated with caspofungin. Cultures are being followed up. Prednisone is continued at 5 mg. 

The patient remains persistently hypotensive and requires prolonged norepinephrine. A trial of dopamine was unsuccessful due to tachycardia. Levophed is being weaned. 

The patient's acute renal failure is being closely monitored, with trends in creatinine, BUN, and electrolytes. Fluid challenge (FC) has been discontinued after finding candidemia. Renal is assessing the need for CVVH on a daily basis. The patient's urine output is difficult to quantify. 

Metastatic malignancy is being evaluated with the family working on a second opinion from an outside oncologist. No other role for intervention based on

   74 yo female with metastatic ovarian adenocarcinoma admitted with
   persistent respiratory failure with multipe failed extubations,
   hypotension requiring prolonged pressor support, acute renal failure
   requiring CVVH, and [**Female First Name (un) 1354**] fungemia.
   # Respiratory Failure: Patient has completed antimicrobial therapy for
   aspiration pneumonia.  She has bilateraly chest tubes in place that are
   currently clamped off. CXR this morning suggests improved pleural
   effusion on right and unchanged on left.  Patient has been intubated
   for a significant period of time, and will likely be difficult to
   extubate successfully in the short-term.

   - Appreciate IP recs. Will consider discontinuing right chest tube and
   will send off cell count, glucose, and culture from left chest tube.
   - Discussed with IP, tentative plan for trach on Wednesday, will need
   to discuss with family. DDAVP available on call for Wednesday. NPO with
   TF shut off at midnight.

   - F/u cultures, last positive on [**10-9**]
   .

   norepinephrine. Failed trial of dopamine secondary to tachycardia.
   Failed wean off of norepinephrine yesterday secondary to decreased UOP
   and MAP~60, although still mentating well.
   - Continue levophed
   - Monitor UOP, lactate, mentation
   - F/u on TFTs per endocrine request

   potassium up to 5.4 from 5.3. FC placed yesterday with UOP of 187cc
   from 1p-12am yesterday (17cc/hr).  Renal is following patient and will
   assess need for CVVH on a daily basis.
   - Trend creatinine, BUN, electrolytes
   - Place FC, monitor UOP
   - Urine lytes pending
   - Renally dose meds, avoid nephrotoxins.
   .
   # Metastatic Malignancy: Provider to provider second opinion requested
   yesterday.
   - Follow-up with oncology.
   -Will need to evalaute patient's goals for care in the setting of
   absence of reversible progression of malignancy
   .
